As President Bush and Congress square off over the Iraq war, most Americans agree with Democrats that a timetable should be set to withdraw troops, and they approve measures to link financing with such a timetable, a CBS News poll finds.

Fifty-seven percent of the respondents said a withdrawal timetable should be set for some time next year, and 38 percent disagreed. One-third said all the troops should be removed now, and 37 percent favored lowering troop levels.

Almost half, 49 percent, said Congress should have the final say on troop levels, and 44 percent said it should be the president. Eighty-three percent of those surveyed said the administration should take the views of Congress into account when making decisions about Iraq.
The report was based on telephone interviews conducted last Monday through Thursday with 994 adults nationwide. It has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
